importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the article's publication, indicating when the news of the charges against Andrew Stanton was reported to the public.
The date when US Customs and Border Patrol supervisor contacted Stanton, leading to further escalation of the case and hostile response from Stanton.
The timeframe when the Wisconsin Statewide Intelligence Center began monitoring Stanton's online activity after receiving a tip about his inquiry into Israeli military locations.
The scheduled pretrial conference date for the case, indicating the timeline of legal proceedings.
The scheduled trial date for Andrew Stanton, marking the final stage of legal proceedings in the case.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period during which the threatening TikTok videos were posted, beginning in August and continuing into October 2025.

keyTakeAways: A Wisconsin man, Andrew Stanton, was charged with threatening federal law enforcement agents, specifically Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) officers, via a series of TikTok videos.
Stanton allegedly called for the killing of ICE agents, including a direct statement: 'If they (ICE) show up to your neighborhood…it’s time we start shooting at you.'
He was also accused of suggesting that mass shootings could be used as a response to federal agents, referencing the September 10 murder of Charlie Kirk, saying 'do a lot more Charlie Kirks.'
Federal investigators were prompted to act after a tip from the Wisconsin Statewide Intelligence Center about Stanton's inquiry into Israeli military locations in Wisconsin and Illinois.
Stanton refused to comply with multiple attempts by federal agents to interview him, including a text message from a US Customs and Border Patrol supervisor, which escalated the situation.
The case reflects broader concerns about violence against federal immigration enforcement personnel amid nationwide criticism of Trump administration immigration tactics.
Stanton is currently in federal detention pending trial and has pleaded not guilty, with his attorney emphasizing that the criminal complaint contains allegations, not proven facts.

namedEntities.name: Andrew Stanton
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The central individual charged in the case, a 38-year-old man from Kenosha, Wisconsin.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He is the primary subject of the article, accused of making threatening posts on TikTok calling for the killing of ICE agents, which led to federal charges.

namedEntities.name: Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A federal agency responsible for immigration enforcement and border control in the United States.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: ICE agents are the specific targets of the threats made by Andrew Stanton in his TikTok videos, forming the core of the legal charges.

namedEntities.name: Wisconsin Statewide Intelligence Center
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A federal office that monitors suspected terrorist activity and suspicious behavior across Wisconsin.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: This entity initiated a tip-based investigation into Andrew Stanton’s online activity, which led to the federal authorities launching a formal inquiry.

namedEntities.name: Charlie Kirk
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A conservative political activist who was murdered on September 10, 2025.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Stanton allegedly referenced the killing of Charlie Kirk in a video, suggesting a pattern of violence against political figures, linking it to his broader ideology.

namedEntities.name: US Customs and Border Patrol
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A federal law enforcement agency under DHS responsible for border security and immigration enforcement.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: A supervisor from this agency directly contacted Stanton, resulting in a hostile exchange and contributing to the escalation of the case.

namedEntities.name: TikTok
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A social media platform used by Andrew Stanton to post videos containing threatening content.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The platform served as the medium through which the threatening messages were distributed, making it a critical vector in the case.

namedEntities.name: Federal prosecutors
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Law enforcement officials representing the federal government in the prosecution of Andrew Stanton.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: They filed the criminal complaint and presented the allegations, including specific video content and statements made by Stanton.

namedEntities.name: John Bradley
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Legal counsel for Andrew Stanton, representing him in court.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He responded to the allegations by asserting that the complaint is based on allegations, not proven facts, and that Stanton is presumed innocent.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Andrew Stanton, a 38-year-old man from Kenosha, Wisconsin, has been charged with threatening federal law enforcement officials, particularly Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) agents, after posting a series of threatening TikTok videos from August to October 2025. In one video, he urged viewers to shoot ICE agents if they appeared in neighborhoods, and in another, he referenced the murder of conservative political activist Charlie Kirk by suggesting 'do a lot more Charlie Kirks.' Federal investigators became aware of Stanton’s online activity after a tip from the Wisconsin Statewide Intelligence Center, which flagged his inquiry into Israeli military locations. Despite multiple attempts to speak with him, Stanton refused contact and responded with hostility, including an exchange with a US Customs and Border Patrol supervisor. He is currently detained pending trial, with a pretrial conference scheduled for December 1, 2025, and a trial set for December 15, 2025. His legal team maintains that the criminal complaint contains only allegations and that he is presumed innocent.
title: Wisconsin man charged after posting TikTok videos calling for the killing of ICE agents, prosecutors say
